metadata.title: In Situ Fabrication of Nano Porous NiO-Capped Ni3P film as Anode for Li-Ion Battery with Different Lithiation Path and Significantly Enhanced Electrochemical Performance

sections.text:
In Situ Fabrication of Nano Porous NiO-Capped Ni3P film as Anode for Li-Ion Battery with Different Lithiation Path and Significantly Enhanced Electrochemical Performance
Junhua Hua,b,*, Peng Wanga,b, Panpan Liua,b, Guoqin Caoa,b, Qian Wanga,b, Meng Weia,b, Jing Maoa,b, Changhao Liangc, Guosheng Shaoa,b,* a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450002, China b State Centre for International Cooperation on Designer Low-carbon and Environmental Materials, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China cKey Laboratory of Materials Physics and Anhui Key Laboratory of Nanomaterials and Nanotechnology, Institute of Solid State Physics, Hefei Institutes of Physical Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Hefei 230031, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 22 March 2016 Received in revised form 22 August 2016 Accepted 9 October 2016 Available online 11 October 2016
Keywords: nano porous NiO film P-rich phosphide nickel phosphide lithium-ion battery
A B S T R A C T
Nickel phosphide (Ni3P) is a promising anode material for lithium-ion batteries owing to its high specific capacity, though significant improvement in its cycling stability is highly desired. Here we propose an effective and low-cost solution via a three-dimensional construction of porous NiO covered Ni3P films over a substrate of Ni foam, through electroless plating of P-rich Ni3P and subsequent in situ oxidation in air. The in situ oxidation of P-rich Ni3P resulted in the formation of nano porous NiO capping layer. Remarkable enhancement in the cycling stability of such a composite anode was thus realized. The initial discharge capacity for a CR2016-type coin cell was as high as 920 mA h g 1, and there was still a reversible capacity of 550 mA h g 1 after 60 cycles at a current density of 38.8 mA g 1. The presence of porous NiO capping layer changed the lithiation path and significantly improved the cycling performance. The decreased resistance in charge transport due to the existence of adequate channels for Li ions diffusion also enhanced rate performance. A pristine Ni3P films was researched as a comparison.
ã 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Electrochimica Acta
journal homepa ge: www.elsev ier .com/locate /e lectacta

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Intense effort in developing high-capacity lithium batteries originates from the growing demand for portable electronic devices and the potential uses in electric vehicles of lithium batteries. At present, transition metal phosphides have attracted great attention as a novel anode material because of their higher gravimetric capacity compared with commercial graphite and lower polarization with respect to fluorides, oxides, and sulphides [1–10]. So far, numerous binary and ternary metal phosphides have been exploited as negative electrodes, e.g. MnP4, CoP3, ZnP2, Zn3P2, InP, GaP, Cu3P, VP, VP2, VP4, FeP, FeP2, and FeP4 [11–23]. However, to date the application of phosphides in practical Li-ion batteries is still seriously impeded by the relatively large initial irreversible loss and poor capacity retention due to huge volume changes from anode reactions associated with the charging-discharging cycles
* Corresponding authors at: School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, 450002, China.
E-mail addresses: hujh@zzu.edu.cn (J. Hu), gsshao@zzu.edu.cn (G. Shao).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2016.10.052 0013-4686/ã 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
[5,24,25]. The electrochemical conversion mechanism to insert Li+
ions to a phosphide in the anode is [26,27]:
MxPy + 3yLi+ + 3ye ! yLi3P + xM (1) Such a conversion reaction between Li+ and metal phosphide
MxPy would cause pronounced change in phase composition, and thus deteriorate the structural integrity of the anode material, which would result in loss of capacity and degrading cycling stability. Repeating conversion processes during charging-discharging would result in pulverization of the anode and finally destroy of its initial structure [28–31]. Additionally, some typical transition metal phosphides are rather compact in phase structures, which is the reason why these materials are resistive to environmental corrosion. However, the dense packing in electrode structures is not helpful for fast lithiation/delithiation of the anode material, leading to low electrochemical response of the battery system.
Among the transition metal phosphides, Ni3P reacts with Li+ at an average voltage about 1 V and induces flat charge and discharge curves separated by about 0.4 V [29–31]. Great endeavor has been made in order to improve the electrochemical performance of the
anode material based on Ni3P powder. In particular, extensive efforts have been made by reducing the particle sizes of Ni3P powders, in order to minimize structural damages in the materials during charging-discharging cycles. For example, it was shown that micrometer-scale Cu3P powders fabricated by a solvothermal method had better cycling performance than that of coarser powders prepared by methods such as ball milling, high temperature sintering and thermal spraying [32,33]. Hall and Trizio demonstrated that refining phosphide powders from the micrometer scale down to nanometer scale led to further improvement of structural stability of the phosphide anode [34– 36]. While refining powders down to nanometer scale could improve the structural integrity effectively, a large irreversible loss from 2000 to 700 mA h g 1 in the first cycle was observed by Xu et al. [37], which was typical to previously reported nano-powders of other phosphide anode materials [38–40]. The formation of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is largely behind the remarkable capacity loss associated with nano-powders, wherein the large specific interfacial area could enhance SEI formation and enlarge loss in capacity during initial cycles. It was not surprising to find that the electrochemical stability of phosphide anodes could also be enhanced by coating Ni3P nano-powder with conductive materials such as carbon materials [24,25,33], as such suitable coatings could help minimizing the structural instability of anode materials, together with decreased charge transfer impedance associated with the lithiation/delithiation process [41,42]. It is, however, worth noting that it is nontrivial to coat nano-powders with well-controlled uniformity in terms of thickness and composition. It is therefore reasonable to envisage that the cycling stability of phosphide anode could be effectively improved through a layered construction of the active material and suitable protective coatings. Structural damage in the phosphide could thus be minimized via decreased lithiation/delithiation depth or the layer thickness in the active anode material, and further structural stability could be provided from suitable coating on the top to allow reduced specific electrode/electrolyte interfacial area and spatial confinement of the active material below. The smaller specific interfacial area than that of the nano-powders is also considered to be helpful to alleviate capacity loss in the initial cycles due to pressed SEI formation [43].
In this work, we present a low-cost technique to construct layered phosphide/NiO structures over the cavity surfaces of foamed Ni. The active film of phosphide material was coated to a substrate of Ni foam using the well-established and low-cost electroless plating method [34]. A porous capping layer of nanocrystalline NiO film was then introduced over the surface of the Ni3P film by in situ oxidation, on the basis that porous transition metal oxides such as CoO, NiO and CuO have been identified as stable materials during the electrochemical cycles [5–7,22]. Such an oxide capped anode based on Ni3P thin-film is shown, for the first time, to offer remarkable enhancement in cycling stability through highly improved structural stability. Compared to naked Ni3P films, after 60 cycles, the discharge capacity of NiO capped Ni3P is 3 times higher, which is much improved than the yields ever reported for Ni3P. The new strategy provides us a cost-effective way, beyond carbon-shell structure, to improve the structure stability and cycling performance by a nano porous capping layer for lithium battery.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental section
sections.text:
The Ni3P phosphide film was coated on the surfaces of interconnected pores throughout substrates of foamed nickel plates (12 mm in diameter, 0.2 mm in thickness), using an electroless plating process conducted in a water bath. The aqueous plating solution consisted of NiSO4 6H2O (44 gL 1), NaH2PO2 H2O
(24.4 gL 1), citric acid monohydrate (16 gL 1), NaAc (18 gL 1), lactic acid (6 gL 1) and tartaric acid (6 gL 1). Before plating, the foamed nickel substrates were subjected to ultrasonic cleaning sequentially in acetone, deionized water, and dilute hydrochloric acid, and then dried in vacuum. The electroless plating was conducted at 90 C for 20 minutes under constant magnetic stirring, with the PH value of electrolyte maintained at 3 4. The resultant phosphide films were typically of an amorphous structure.
The as-plated films were then annealed at 600 C for 30 minutes in argon gas and in air respectively, and cooled down to room temperature within the furnace. This resulted in two kinds of annealed Ni3P film samples, porous NiO-capped Ni3P film (PNCP) in air and naked Ni3P in argon gas. The structure and surface morphology of the films thus obtained were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Ultima IV) with the Cu Ka radiation, and field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Sirion-200) equipped with an energy disperse X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy system, respectively.
Electrochemical performance was investigated with a CR2016type of two-electrode half cell, using lithium foil as the negative electrode. The electrolyte was made of 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DMC) with the volumetric EC/DMC ratio being 1:1. The separator was in the form of micro-porous film of polypropylene. The nickel foam coated with Ni3P films annealed in either air or argon gas were used as the anode. The CR2016-type coin cells were assembled in a glove box filled with high-purity Ar (Mbraun-MBC-Q13-588, O2< 0.1 ppm, H2O < 0.1 ppm). The galvanostatic charge-discharge tests were conducted on a LAND CT2001A battery testing system in the voltage range of 0.01 to 3.0 V (versus Li/Li+) in the incubator with the constant temperature at 25 C. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were conducted on an electrochemical workstation (PARSTAT 4000, at 25 C). For the specific capacity evaluation, the net weight of Ni3P layer was measure before and after plating of Ni3P coating. For NiO-capped Ni3P film, the total weight of NiO and Ni3P was measured by using a microbalance with readability of 10 mg (Mettler Toledo MS105, Switzerland). When the capacity was determined, the error estimation has been taken into account. The capacity was measured for 3 times and the error bar was used for error estimations. And the average values were used for discussion.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The as-plated film was in an amorphous state. Fig. 1a shows XRD patterns of as-deposited phosphide film. Only nickel peaks from the foamed Ni substrate are presented, which indicates an amorphous state of the as-deposited phosphide. Figs. Fig.11(b) and
Fig. 11(c) show the XRD patterns of the annealed phosphide in Ar gas and air, respectively. Except for the diffraction peaks from Ni substrate, after annealing in both atmosphere, the tetragonal structure of Ni3P (a = b = 8.952 Å, c = 4.338 Å) was formed. The formation of an additional NiO phase in the latter was attributed to reaction with oxygen in air during annealing. It was reported that chemically reduced Ni can also exist in the electroless plated phosphide film as a minor phase [24,34], though it will be shown later that this is not the case here owing to enrichment of P in the phosphide film.
Fig. 2(a) shows the overall morphology of the Ni foam, and Fig. 2(b) shows a largely smooth surface of the interconnected cavities in the Ni foam. Fig. 2(c–f) compare the morphology of coated Ni foam after annealing in Ar gas and air, respectively. It can be seen that, before electroless plating, the surface of the foamed
Fig. 2. Secondary electron SEM images from: (a, b) uncoated Ni foam with higher mag annealed in Ar; (d, f) sample annealed in air. Note the highly rough surface with the e
Ni substrate consisted of equiaxed Ni grains of the size of about 10 mm. The surface was completely covered by the phosphide layer after plating. The electroless plated phosphide film consists of particles with the diameter of 100 nm and the surface is relatively compact (Fig. 2c and e). Meanwhile, Fig. 2(d, f) exhibited evidently different morphological features from the sample annealed in air. The surface morphology of the sample annealed in air shows a relatively porous structure, with some pores shown to go downward to the material below (Fig. 2f and Fig. 3a in detail). And the porous structure is composed by 3 dimension interconnected fiber-like branches. The results from energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy for the Ni3P layer proved that the atomic Ni/P ratio is about 2.4. According to the XRD result, the phosphide pattern is in excellent agreement with the standard powder pattern for the Ni3P phase. The film is therefore regarded as a P-rich Ni3P phase. The high content of P can help lower the crystallization temperature of the amorphous phosphide film [40]. As indicated by eqn. (1), in a certain sense, the contents of P determine the charge–discharge capacity of the metal phosphides. The porous nature of the NiO capping layer was also clearly proved by surfacial elemental mapping. A typical selected area shown by a secondary
nification showing smooth surface of the interconnected cavities (b); (c, e) sample xistence of penetrating pores.
electrons image in Fig. 3b was analyzed concerning element distribution. Imaging with secondary electrons provides information about morphology and surface topography. The contrast is dominated by the so-called edge effect, which is also sensitive to the porous structure on the surface. Fig. 3c and d proves the surface of the sample annealed in air consists mainly of Ni and O, indicating that the surface is covered by an oxide layer. The overlapped mapping of Ni and O distribution on the PNCP surface (Fig. 3c) doesn’t show any colour contrast, and pores in the oxide are shown as dark spots. The porous surface covered the whole Ni3P surface. The carbon was previously deposited on the surface to help diminish static electricity accumulation during SEM observation.
The typical cross section image of sample annealed in air, is shown in Fig. 4. The low-magnification inset in Fig. 4(a) shows a selected region around a tube-like cavity in the substrate Ni foam. The outer surface of Ni3P coating is covered with a coarse thin layer of materials with lower atomic mass, i.e. the NiO formed during annealing in air. The Ni3P film is about 1.3 mm in thickness. The elemental mapping (Fig. 4 b d) is supportive that the Ni3P coating is covered by a much thinner NiO layer less than 100 nm in thickness, with the oxygen mapping corresponding to the NiO layer indicated in Fig. 4(a). An overall view for the inset in Fig. 4(a) is shown in Fig. 4f. The homogeneous distribution of Ni and P in the phosphide films is attributable to their simultaneous formation by the redox reactions [24,28,44].
Ni2+ + H2PO2— + H2O ! H2PO32— +2H+ + Ni (2)
3H2PO2— + H+! HPO32—+ 3H2O + 2P (3) So that both elements could mix randomly at an atomic scale to
form an amorphous film (Fig. 1a). As was determined by the EDX quantification, the as-plated phosphide was rich in P element.
During annealing in air, co-oxidation of both Ni and P occurred over the surface of the Ni3P film and the formation of volatile P oxide accounted for the formation of nano-or micro-pores in the NiO film. The formation of P-rich amorphous Ni3P layer contributed to void formation [45–47].
Fig. 5a shows the galvanostatic charge/discharge response of the PNCP films, recorded in the potential range of 0.01 V to 3.0 V at a current density of 38.8 mA g 1 (0.1C). The initial discharge capacity was 920 mA h g 1, and the retained capacity after the 10th cycle was still as high as 610 mA h g 1, which was still two-third of the initial capacity. This is remarkably higher than what achieved in previous reports, which showed that the capacity retention for phosphide electrodes after the first cycle was never higher than 45%, even by compositing phosphide powder with carbon or by powder refining [34,37–39]. The establishment of SEI mainly accounts for the high capacity loss in the initial cycles for nickel phosphide based anodes. The direct contact of transition metal phosphide with electrolyte will also cause the catalyzed decomposition of organic molecules. Both processes occurred at a low potential [48–51]. It was reported that for the NiO anode materials, the energy loss due to the SEI formation is relatively low [5–7,11,22]. In the present case, the presence of an oxide layer can diminish the energy loss in the initial cycles as an intermediate layer between active material and electrolyte. The capping NiO is also expected to offer mechanical reinforcement to hold the Ni3P film a piece, while pores through the oxide can provide spatial allowance to accommodate volumetric expansion associated with the lithiation of the electrode.
Indeed, capacity loss for the Ni3P film without a NiO capping layer is shown in Fig. 5b for comparison. For the naked Ni3P film without NiO capping, nearly half capacity loss occurred in the second cycle. For PNCP (Fig. 5a), decay in the capacity was low after the first cycle and even after 60 cycles the discharge capacity of 550 mA h g 1, or 60% of the initial capacity, was still retained. Also,
a broad plateau at the potential from 1.5 V to 1.0 V existed in the discharge curve for NiO-capped Ni3P film, which corresponded to the successive phase transformation from Ni3P to Li3P through lithiation of the electrode [3,37–39,52]. During the delithiation scan, the anodic plateaus at the potential of about 2.2 V and 1.5 V are associated with the reformation of Ni3P [37]. After 25 cycles, specific capacity of pure Ni3P film decreased to less than 200 mA h g 1. This confirms the fairly impressive benefit from utilizing a porous NiO capping layer in improving the cycling stability of the electrode.
Fig. 5a and b shows some difference in anodic and cathodic reactions, indicating that porous NiO film did change reaction path in the cycling [38,39]. The lithium storage performance of Ni3P–Ni arrays was characterized by cyclic voltammetry (CV) to identify the influence of porous NiO on the electrochemical reaction undergone by the Ni3P. Fig. 6a and b shows CV curves of the PNCP and bare Ni3P electrode in the 0.01–3 V versus Li/Li+ potential window at a scan rate of 0.05 mV s 1. The cathodic and anodic peaks are corresponding well with the discharge-charge plateaus in Fig. 5. During the de-lithiation scan the anodic peak at the potential of about 2.3-2.4 V is associated with the re-formation of Ni3P [31], which is similar for both electrodes. An additional anodic peak appeared in Fig. 6 b, indicating Li+ extraction from different Li+
insertion products [2,31]. The successive phase transformation upon lithium-ion insertion via crystalline Ni3P to form Li3P alloy occurred around the potential of 1.0 V [2,31]. Accordingly, the electrode reaction of Ni3P was expressed as:
Ni3P + 3(1-x) Li ,3 (1-x) Ni + (1-x) Li3P + x “Ni3P” unreacted (x < 1)(4) The positive shift of cathodic reaction peaks can be observed by
the presence of porous oxide layer (Fig. 6a and b). The formation of LiP, instead of Li3P, would contribute to the reaction at the low potential 0.73 V [31]. For the lithiation reaction to generate LiP, it delivers a low capacity of 130 mA h g 1, which is the reason that naked Ni3P demonstrates a lower capacity. At the same time, the interval between anodic and cathodic peaks is suggested as the polarization of the electrode. Therefore, PNCP electrode shows the lower polarization as indicated in Fig. 6. The low polarization would improve cycling performance (Fig. 7).
In Fig. 7, we compared the cycling performances of PNCP film and the naked Ni3P film as electrodes. After 60 cycles, the PNCP film still delivered a capacity of 558 mA h g 1, which is about 91% of the capacity in 2nd cycle and is remarkably more stable than the naked Ni3P film. For the naked Ni3P film, a continuing decay in the capacity led to a specific capacity as low as 147 mA h g 1 after 60 cycles. The coulombic efficiency was high for both PNCP and naked electrodes (filled data points). However, the PNCP electrode demonstrated a more stable coulombic efficiency. In previous literatures, the electrodeposited Ni3P never demonstrated a stable capacity higher than this value within 60 cycles [31,48–50]. The fabrication of core-shell and other hybridizing structures can retain 450 mA h g 1 and 200 mA h g 1 within 50 cycles, respectively in [6,53]. By construction of C@Ni3P/Ni/C complicated structure, the energy loss within 60 cycles with respect to the 2nd cycle was only more than 30% [54,55]. It is worth pointing out that electrodes made of compact NiO alone also suffers from rapid capacity decay during charging/discharging cycles, which is caused by severe pulverization associated to significant volumes changes from the lithiation/delithiation processes. It was observed that the construction of nano-porous material was an effective way to overcome this drawback for NiO material [56,57]. For PNCP electrode, a decline near 60 cycles was observed. A comparison of CV curves at 2rd and 61st cycles (Fig. 8) demonstrated an evident negative shift of cathode reaction potential, which enhanced the polarization of electrode.
It is also reasonable to postulate that the porous NiO would permit adequate infiltration of electrolyte to the underlining active phosphide layer for quick transport of Li+ ions during chargingdischarging cycles. The rate capabilities for the phosphide electrodes with and without the porous NiO capping layer are
and naked Ni3P film as the anode. The error estimation was demonstrated by error
compared in Fig. 9a. The capacities of PNCP film and Ni3P film were 600 mA h g 1 and 340 mA h g 1 at the current density of 19.4 mA g 1 (0.05C), respectively. When the current density increased to 388 mA g 1 (1C), the respective capacity for the PNCP and Ni3P electrodes dropped to about 360 mA h g 1 and 130 mA h g 1. Moreover, when the current density was dropped back to 19.4 mA g 1 (0.05C), the loss in the capacity was reversely recovered back to about 580 mA h g 1 for the electrode of the PNCP film, while the capacity for the naked Ni3P electrode was recovered to a lesser extent, back to 220 mA h g 1. Overall capacity
retention was about 97% for the PNCP electrode and 65% for the naked phosphide film, respectively. The radical improvement in rate capability for the PNCP electrode is attributable to highly reduced damage in the electrode structure and the advantages of porous NiO layer in shortening depth for lithium insertion/ extraction, together with shortcuts for electrolyte to access the phosphide material below. A comparison of two electrode surface SEM images after 100 cycles at 0.1C. is shown as Fig. 10. In Fig. 10a, the exposure of Ni substrate was indicated by arrows, which proved the damage of Ni3P during the cycling. For PNCP electrode, the surface was peeling-free. The beneficial effect of the porous NiO capping layer on Li+ transport and structural integrity was also supported by the results of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), which revealed significantly lowered resistance in charge transport due to the existence of porous NiO. Fig. 9b shows the impedance plots for electrodes of PNCP and Ni3P films, recorded from 0.01 Hz to 10 kHz. It is seen that the starting point of the impedance curve of Ni3P films is not zero, implying existence of the additional resistance in the system. Compared with the plot for the naked Ni3P film, the impedance plot for the PNCP film exhibits a smaller semicircle in the medium frequency region, suggesting a lower electron transfer resistance. This can be attributed to the combined effects such as good structural integrity, together with adequate porous channel for electrolyte to access the phosphide materials beneath the NiO capping.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A new low-cost approach has been developed in order to overcome the serious problem of large capacity decay of phosphide electrodes for Li ion batteries, via electroless plating of Ni3P over Ni foam, followed by an annealing in air to induce a nano-porous layer of NiO, with the nickel foam acting as a current collector and the
oxide capped phosphide as active electrode. The porous nanocrystalline NiO layer below 100 nm in thickness acts as a capping layer to the phosphide film beneath, which contributes to remarkable improvement of the cycling stability of composite electrode. Compared to naked Ni3P films, an electrode made of porous NiO capped Ni3P film was shown to enable remarkably reduced capacity loss, so that 60% of the initial high discharge capacity of 920 mA h g 1 was retained (550 mA h g 1) after 60 cycles at a current density of 38.8 mA h g 1. Based on the electrochemical measurement, it is speculated the porous nanoNiO capping layer enabled high cycling stability of the composite electrode, through (a) changing lithiation reaction path; (b) decreasing of impedance by allowing porous channels for adequate electrolyte access to promote Li+ ion transport, and (c) offering spatial allowance to minimize local stress from volumetric changes during discharging-charging cycles. The overall benefit also resulted in improvement in cycling and rate performance.

sections.text: We acknowledge financial support from the the Basic Research Program, Ministry of Science and Technology of China (no. 2014CB931704) and National Science Foundation of China (no. 51001091, 11174256, 91233101, and 51571182).

metadata.abstractText: Nickel phosphide (Ni3P) is a promising anode material for lithium-ion batteries owing to its high specific capacity, though significant improvement in its cycling stability is highly desired. Here we propose an effective and low-cost solution via a three-dimensional construction of porous NiO covered Ni3P films over a substrate of Ni foam, through electroless plating of P-rich Ni3P and subsequent in situ oxidation in air. The in situ oxidation of P-rich Ni3P resulted in the formation of nano porous NiO capping layer. Remarkable enhancement in the cycling stability of such a composite anode was thus realized. The initial discharge capacity for a CR2016-type coin cell was as high as 920 mA h g , and there was still a reversible capacity of 550 mA h g 1 after 60 cycles at a current density of 38.8 mA g . The presence of porous NiO capping layer changed the lithiation path and significantly improved the cycling performance. The decreased resistance in charge transport due to the existence of adequate channels for Li ions diffusion also enhanced rate performance. A pristine Ni3P films was researched as a comparison. ã 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
